A guide to running Eberron campaigns using the Fate system.

This document works alongside the Eberron Setting Guide (for world lore) and the Player’s Guide (for character creation).

Running Eberron

Eberron has a distinctive tone that sets it apart from traditional fantasy. Your job as GM is to embody that tone in play.

The Core Principles

Everything Is Morally Complicated

There are no pure heroes or irredeemable villains in Eberron. The Silver Flame church genuinely fights evil—and also conducted a purge that nearly wiped out lycanthropes and shifters. House Cannith created the warforged, giving rise to a new form of life—and did so to profit from a century of war. The Lord of Blades may be a terrorist, or may be the only one fighting for warforged liberation.

When you create NPCs, give them understandable motivations. When you present factions, show their virtues alongside their flaws. When players make choices, let those choices have real consequences—but not simple ones.

Don’t tell the players that the Church of the Silver Flame is good or evil. Show them a Thrane priest who heals the sick for free—and then show them another who treats shifters with barely concealed disgust. Let players form their own opinions.

The War Isn’t Over

The Last War ended with the Treaty of Thronehold, but a hundred years of conflict don’t just evaporate. Every adult in Khorvaire remembers the war. Many fought in it. Refugees from Cyre have no home to return to. Veterans carry physical and mental scars. The nations watch each other across borders, waiting for the next betrayal.

Use the war as background texture constantly:

  • NPCs mention relatives lost in the war
  • Buildings bear damage from battles fought years ago
  • Political tensions flare when characters of different nationalities interact
  • Warforged face discrimination from those who see them as weapons, not people
  • Cyran refugees are everywhere, stateless and bitter

Intrigue and Conspiracy

Nothing in Eberron is what it seems on the surface. Every organization has secrets. Every powerful figure has hidden agendas. Conspiracies nest inside conspiracies.

The Aurum manipulates commerce and politics. The Dreaming Dark infiltrates through dreams. The Lords of Dust have plans spanning millennia. The Chamber’s dragons pursue the Draconic Prophecy through proxies. The dragonmarked houses pursue their own interests across national borders.

Build layers into your mysteries. When players solve one conspiracy, they should glimpse another beneath it. Not everything needs an answer—some mysteries should remain mysteries.

Cinematic Action

Eberron is pulp adventure, not gritty realism. Fights happen on lightning rails racing through the Mournland. Chases unfold across Sharn’s vertical cityscape. Ancient ruins contain elaborate traps and awakening horrors.

Push for dynamic locations and dramatic situations:

  • “You’re fighting on a rain-slick bridge between two towers, five hundred feet above Lower Dura.”
  • “The train lurches as something massive strikes it from beneath the track.”
  • “The ritual circle flares with light. You have until the moons align—maybe five minutes.”

Use zones aggressively. Create environmental hazards. Let players destroy the scenery. Embrace the chaos.

Building Adversaries

The Fate Adversary Toolkit provides a framework for building opposition based on narrative role rather than power level. Choose adversary types based on the story function you need.

Adversary Types

Threats

Threats exist to be hit once and go down. They’re dangerous in numbers but not individually durable. Use them to create chaos and drain resources.

Building Threats:

  • One aspect (their concept: Daask Street Thug, Emerald Claw Initiate)
  • One or two skills at Average (+1) or Fair (+2)
  • No stress track—any successful hit takes them out
  • Attack in groups using teamwork (+1 per additional threat, max +3)

When to use: Swarms of enemies, dangerous-but-fragile minions, time pressure through numbers.

Example: Boromar Thugs Halfling Street Muscle Skills: Fight Average (+1), Notice Average (+1) A group of 4 attacks at Fair (+2). Each hit removes one thug.

Fillers

Fillers are grouped enemies that share a stress track. They’re tougher than threats but still exist to be mowed down.

Building Fillers:

  • One aspect for the group
  • One or two skills at Fair (+2) or Good (+3)
  • Shared stress track (1 box per member)
  • Attack as one unit with teamwork bonus
  • Removing stress removes individuals from the fight

When to use: Guards, cultists, mercenary squads—opposition that should feel substantial but not individually memorable.

Example: Emerald Claw Squad (4 soldiers) Vol’s Faithful Servants Skills: Fight Fair (+2), Shoot Fair (+2), Will Average (+1) Stress: [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] Attack at Great (+4) with teamwork. Each stress removes one soldier.

Hitters

Hitters deal damage and can take a few hits before going down. They’re the dangerous combatants that make fights threatening.

Building Hitters:

  • High concept and one other aspect
  • Peak skill at Good (+3) or Great (+4)
  • 2-3 supporting skills
  • Stress track (2-3 boxes)
  • One consequence (mild or moderate)
  • Optional: One stunt that makes them distinctive

When to use: Assassins, elite guards, dangerous monsters, anyone who should make the party sweat.

Example: House Deneith Blademark Professional Mercenary Honor in Service Skills: Fight Great (+4), Athletics Good (+3), Notice Fair (+2), Physique Fair (+2) Stunt: Shield Wall—+2 to defense when fighting alongside allies Stress: [ ] [ ] [ ] Consequence: Moderate [ ]

Bosses

Bosses are major antagonists who can threaten the whole party. They should feel like they could be player characters—or more.

Building Bosses:

  • Full five aspects
  • Skills in a pyramid (peak at Superb +5 or higher for truly legendary foes)
  • Multiple stunts
  • Full stress track
  • Full consequence slots
  • Boss Features (pick 1-3):
    • Extra Actions: Acts twice per exchange, or once per PC
    • Damage Absorption: Requires multiple stress boxes to fill one box
    • Zone Control: Free invokes on aspects in their territory
    • Lieutenants: Brings hitters or fillers into the fight
    • Recovery: Clears a mild consequence at end of scene, or can flee to return later
    • Special Weakness: Takes extra stress from specific attacks (drives investigation)

When to use: Campaign villains, faction leaders, monsters that define an adventure.

Example: The Lord of Blades Warforged Prophet of Revolution Flesh Is Weakness The Mournland Is Our Homeland Built for War, Born to Lead No Compromise with the Breathers

Skills: Fight Fantastic (+6), Provoke Superb (+5), Will Superb (+5), Physique Great (+4), Lore Great (+4), Athletics Good (+3), Notice Good (+3)

Stunts:

  • Adamantine Blades: Weapon:2 on Fight attacks
  • Inspiring Presence: Warforged allies get +2 to Will when they can see him
  • Machine Perfection: Immune to poison, disease, and fear

Boss Features: Extra Actions (acts twice), Lieutenants (warforged hitters)

Stress: [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] Consequences: Mild [ ] | Moderate [ ] | Severe [ ]

Obstacles and Constraints

Not all opposition fights back. Obstacles and constraints create problems that must be overcome or worked around.

Obstacles

Things that block progress or threaten harm. They don’t take actions—they just are.

Blocks must be overcome to proceed:

  • Locked Cannith vault door (Burglary Great +4 to pick, Physique Legendary +8 to force)
  • Magical ward (Lore Superb +5 to dispel, or find another way)
  • Sheer cliff face (Athletics Good +3 to climb)

Hazards attack passively or on a trigger:

  • Poison gas cloud (attacks Physique at Good +3 each exchange)
  • Unstable floor (attacks Athletics at Fair +2 when you move through the zone)
  • Fire spreading through the building (attacks Physique at +2, increasing by +1 each exchange)

Distrations demand attention or create consequences:

  • Civilians in danger (ignore them and gain Innocent Blood on Your Hands)
  • Evidence about to be destroyed (overcome Resources Good +3 to preserve it)
  • Reinforcements arriving (deal with them or face fillers next exchange)

Example: Cannith Security Ward Glowing Sigils Pulse with Warning To bypass: Lore Superb (+5) to dispel, or Burglary Great (+4) to find the physical component If triggered: Attacks everyone in zone at Great (+4) with lightning, then alerts House Cannith

Constraints

Constraints are situational aspects that limit options without being overcome directly. They shape the scene.

  • Crowded Marketplace—collateral damage, witnesses everywhere
  • Diplomatic Immunity—can’t just arrest them
  • Eyes of the Twelve—House agents are watching
  • No Magic Zone—manifest zone suppresses arcane effects
  • Time is Running Out—represented by a countdown

Constraints should be invokable by both sides and create interesting choices.

Countdowns

Countdowns create urgency. Something bad happens when they complete.

Building Countdowns:

  • Define what happens at zero
  • Set the number of boxes (3-6 typically)
  • Decide what advances the countdown:
    • Time: Advances each exchange or scene
    • Action: Advances when enemies act or succeed
    • Failure: Advances when PCs fail key rolls
    • Neglect: Advances when PCs ignore the threat

The countdown is visible to players. The tension comes from knowing what’s coming.

Example: Ritual Completion The Emerald Claw is raising a bone knight. When complete, the battle gets much harder. [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] Advances each exchange. PCs can spend actions to disrupt (overcome Lore Good +3 to remove a box).

Example: Airship Going Down The elemental ring is damaged. When this fills, the ship crashes. [ ] [ ] [ ] Advances when: Taking hull damage, failed piloting checks, or each exchange after the second. PCs can repair (Crafts Good +3) to remove a box.

Example: Cover Blown The party is infiltrating a Daask stronghold. When this fills, the alarm sounds. [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ] Advances when: Failed Stealth or Deceive rolls, suspicious activity noticed, time passes.

Eberron Adversary Categories

Different Eberron threats fill different adversary roles:

Eberron Threat Typical Role Notes
Daask street thugs Threats Dangerous in packs, fragile individually
Emerald Claw soldiers Fillers Trained and organized
House Deneith blademarks Hitters Professional, well-equipped
Karrnathi undead soldiers Fillers/Hitters Don’t break, don’t tire
Living spells Hitters/Bosses Aspects define their danger
Quori-possessed agents Hitters Deceptive, flee when host is defeated
Warforged soldiers (Lord of Blades) Hitters Fanatic, won’t surrender
Daelkyr Bosses Reality-warping horrors
Dragon (Chamber agent) Bosses Ancient, cunning, playing long games
Overlord servant Boss Campaign-ending threat

Factions as Characters

Eberron’s factions are active forces in the world. Treat major factions as characters with their own aspects and agendas.

The Dragonmarked Houses

Each House functions as an economic power that transcends national borders.

House Cannith (Making)

  • Makers of Everything Worth Making
  • The House Is Divided Three Ways (Cannith South, West, and East compete)
  • Agenda: Reunify the House, recover pre-war secrets, restore their monopoly on creation

House Deneith (Sentinel)

  • Blades for Hire
  • Honor in Service
  • Agenda: Expand their mercenary operations, become indispensable to all nations

House Jorasco (Healing)

  • Healing for a Price
  • Everyone Needs Us Eventually
  • Agenda: Maintain their monopoly on magical healing, expand into new markets

House Kundarak (Warding)

  • Safest Vaults in Khorvaire
  • We Know Everyone’s Secrets
  • Agenda: Control banking and security across all nations

House Lyrandar (Storm)

  • Masters of Sea and Sky
  • The Khoravar Deserve Their Own Nation
  • Agenda: Dominate transportation, possibly carve out a half-elf homeland

House Medani (Detection)

  • We See the Threats You Don’t
  • Caught Between House and Nation
  • Agenda: Provide security services, remain neutral in coming conflicts

House Orien (Passage)

  • We Keep Khorvaire Connected
  • House Cannith Stole Our Thunder (lightning rail competition)
  • Agenda: Rebuild trade routes damaged by war, compete with Lyrandar

House Phiarlan (Shadow)

  • Entertainers by Day, Spies by Night
  • The Shadow Schism Still Bleeds
  • Agenda: Gather intelligence, maintain artistic dominance, counter House Thuranni

House Sivis (Scribing)

  • Words Are Our Currency
  • Neutral in All Conflicts
  • Agenda: Control communication, serve as neutral intermediaries

House Tharashk (Finding)

  • We Find What You’ve Lost
  • Monster Hunters for Hire
  • Agenda: Expand prospecting operations, hire out monstrous mercenaries

House Thuranni (Shadow)

  • The Shadow in the Night
  • Born from Betrayal
  • Agenda: Eliminate House Phiarlan’s dominance, expand assassination services

House Vadalis (Handling)

  • Breeders of the Finest Beasts
  • Nature Bent to Purpose
  • Agenda: Develop new magebred creatures, supply beasts of war and labor

Criminal Organizations

The Boromar Clan

  • Sharn’s Oldest Criminal Family
  • Halfling Hospitality (Offer You Can’t Refuse)
  • Agenda: Control Sharn’s underworld, fight off Daask incursion

Daask

  • Droaam’s Monster Mob
  • We Take What We Want
  • Agenda: Seize territory from established crime, prove monsters’ worth

House Tarkanan

  • Aberrant Marks Are Our Strength
  • Outcasts and Survivors
  • Agenda: Protect aberrant dragonmarked, strike at the Houses that persecuted them

National Powers

Breland

  • Democracy and Progress
  • King Boranel Holds It Together—Barely
  • Agenda: Maintain peace, expand democratic institutions, stay ahead economically

Aundair

  • Knowledge Is Power
  • Queen Aurala Dreams of Galifar
  • Agenda: Restore Galifar with Aundair at its head, through magic or politics

Karrnath

  • Strength Through Discipline
  • The Dead Still Serve
  • Agenda: Recover from war losses, distance themselves from their undead past

Thrane

  • Faith and Nation, Nation and Faith
  • The Council of Cardinals Rules
  • Agenda: Spread the Silver Flame, maintain theocratic control

Darguun

  • Goblinoid Nation Reborn
  • Lhesh Haruuc’s Fragile Peace
  • Agenda: Gain legitimacy, unify the clans, recover Dhakaani glory

Secret Powers

The Aurum

  • Gold Moves the World
  • Concordians Pull the Strings
  • Agenda: Control Khorvaire through economic manipulation

The Chamber

  • Dragons Watching Dragons
  • The Prophecy Must Be Fulfilled (Our Way)
  • Agenda: Guide the Draconic Prophecy’s fulfillment

The Lords of Dust

  • Ancient Evil, Patient Plans
  • The Overlords Will Rise Again
  • Agenda: Free the Overlords imprisoned by the Silver Flame

The Dreaming Dark

  • Nightmares Made Flesh
  • We Are Already Inside
  • Agenda: Prevent il-Lashtavar from transforming, control mortal civilization

The Emerald Claw

  • Vol’s Chosen
  • Death Is Just Another Form of Service
  • Agenda: Serve the Blood of Vol (or Lady Illmarrow’s secret agenda)

Compels in Eberron

Compels drive story and earn players fate points. Eberron’s themes provide rich compel opportunities.

War Compels

Cyran Refugee → “You recognize that merchant—he commanded the Brelish unit that sacked your hometown.”

Karrnathi Veteran → “The Aundairian envoy sneers at your accent. Your hand moves to your sword.”

Warforged Soldier → “The child screams and runs. ‘Monster! War machine!’ The crowd turns hostile.”

House Compels

Heir to House Cannith → “Your house contacts have found you—and they’re not here to help. They’re here to bring you back.”

Mark of Finding → “The Tharashk prospectors recognize your mark. They insist you help them—family obligation.”

Intrigue Compels

Trust No One → “Your paranoia is right for once—but you’ve been so suspicious that no one believes your warning.”

I Know Everyone Who Matters → “You recognize the assassin—she’s the daughter of an old ally. Can you really turn her in?”

Setting Compels

Sharn Native → “This is your home turf, which means you can’t ignore the gang moving into your old neighborhood.”

Morgrave Scholar → “The artifact they’re selling is clearly stolen from Xen’drik. Your professional ethics demand you intervene.”

Campaign Frameworks

Here are structures for different campaign types in Eberron.

The Inquisitive Agency

The party runs a detective/problem-solving business in Sharn.

Starting Situation: The characters have an office (or share one), a reputation (good or bad), and need for work.

Campaign Aspects:

  • Inquisitives for Hire
  • Sharn’s Underbelly Knows Us
  • Everyone Has Secrets

Episode Structure: Clients bring problems. Investigations reveal layers of conspiracy. Solutions create new enemies and allies.

Faction Involvement: Start local (Boromar, Watch, local merchants), escalate to Houses and national interests.

Recurring Elements:

  • A rival agency
  • A Watch contact (helpful or hostile)
  • A recurring client with increasingly dangerous problems
  • A mystery that connects multiple cases

The Xen’drik Expedition

The party explores the mysterious southern continent.

Starting Situation: The characters have a patron (Morgrave, a House, an independent collector) and a ship or airship passage.

Campaign Aspects:

  • Fortune and Glory in the Ruins
  • The Giants Left Secrets Behind
  • Xen’drik Changes You

Episode Structure: Expeditions to specific sites. Each site has its own dangers, puzzles, and treasures. The journey is as dangerous as the destination.

Faction Involvement: Competing expeditions, drow factions, elemental threats, giant remnants.

Recurring Elements:

  • A rival expedition leader
  • A guide with their own agenda
  • An artifact that connects multiple expeditions
  • The Traveler’s Curse (things in Xen’drik never stay the same)

The Last War Never Ended

The party are operatives in an ongoing shadow war.

Starting Situation: The characters work for a nation, a house, or an independent power broker. The peace is a fiction.

Campaign Aspects:

  • Cold War Heating Up
  • Spies and Assassins
  • Everyone’s Playing Everyone

Episode Structure: Missions with clear objectives that reveal larger conspiracies. Moral compromises. Betrayals and shifting alliances.

Faction Involvement: National intelligence services (Dark Lanterns, Royal Eyes, Twelve), dragonmarked house interests, secret societies.

Recurring Elements:

  • A handler who knows more than they say
  • Operatives from other nations (some become allies, some enemies)
  • A conspiracy that transcends national boundaries
  • The question: who do you really serve?

Mournland Salvage

The party ventures into the dead nation to recover what was lost.

Starting Situation: The characters are salvagers, treasure hunters, or seekers of lost family/artifacts.

Campaign Aspects:

  • Nothing Lives in the Mournland (Except What Shouldn’t)
  • Treasures Worth Dying For
  • The Mourning’s Mystery

Episode Structure: Expeditions into the Mournland. Each trip is a survival challenge. The deeper you go, the stranger it gets.

Faction Involvement: Other salvage crews, Lord of Blades’ warforged, Cyran ghosts, living spells, the enigma of the Mourning itself.

Recurring Elements:

  • The Dead-Gray Mist and what lives in it
  • A map with locations that shouldn’t exist
  • Artifacts that work wrong outside the Mournland
  • Clues to what actually happened on the Day of Mourning

Dragonmarked Intrigue

The party navigates house politics and interhouse competition.

Starting Situation: The characters are house members, excoriate outcasts, or caught between house interests.

Campaign Aspects:

  • Blood and Business
  • The Korth Edicts Bind Us
  • Aberrant Marks Are the True Threat (Or Are They?)

Episode Structure: Assignments from house superiors, competition with rival houses, internal house politics.

Faction Involvement: All the houses, house Tarkanan, national governments trying to break house power.

Recurring Elements:

  • A rival within your own house
  • An excoriate with a grudge
  • A secret that could destroy your house
  • The question of what the marks really mean

Scene Types

Investigation Scenes

Eberron investigations often involve magical elements.

Information Sources:

  • Speak with Dead (expensive, limited, may be compromised)
  • Divination magic (blocked by wards, gives cryptic results)
  • Dragonmark powers (House Medani detection, House Tharashk tracking)
  • Mundane investigation enhanced by magic (detecting magical residue, identifying alchemical compounds)

Complications:

  • Evidence has been magically altered
  • Witnesses’ memories have been modified
  • The crime scene is warded against divination
  • Someone else is investigating—and getting in the way

Chase Scenes

Sharn’s vertical layout makes chases dynamic.

Zone Ideas for Sharn Chases:

  • Crowded market bridge
  • Plunging through a garbage chute
  • Leaping between towers
  • Skycoach chase
  • Industrial district catwalks
  • Cogs machinery maze

Chase Complications:

  • Magical hazards (industrial magic gone wrong)
  • Bystanders in danger
  • Vertical drops (fall damage or opportunities)
  • Weather (Sharn’s artificial climate can be disrupted)

Social Scenes

Eberron social scenes involve navigating complex relationships.

High Society: Galas, house gatherings, noble courts. Aspects matter—being underdressed, inappropriate nationality, wrong house.

Underworld: Taverns, gambling dens, Daask territory. Different rules apply. Showing weakness is dangerous.

Political: Council meetings, treaty negotiations, church gatherings. Every word is parsed. Every alliance is temporary.

Create Advantage actions in social scenes should create aspects that can be invoked in later interactions or conflicts.

Combat Scenes

Make fights dynamic and meaningful.

Environmental Elements:

  • Magical lighting (everbright, continual flame—can be disrupted)
  • Vertical space (multiple levels, falling hazards)
  • Magical devices (control panels, arcane machinery)
  • Unstable structures (war damage, ancient ruins)

Stakes Beyond Survival:

  • Protect the witnesses
  • Stop the ritual
  • Catch them before they escape
  • Don’t destroy the evidence

The Bronze Rule for Eberron

Everything can be a character. This is especially useful for Eberron’s unique elements.

Airships

Lyrandar Airship “Storm’s Pride”

  • Soarwood Hull, Bound Elemental
  • Captain Alia d’Lyrandar’s Pride and Joy
  • Skills: Drive Good (+3) for maneuverability, Physique Fair (+2) for structural integrity
  • Stress: [ ] [ ] [ ] [ ]
  • Consequences: Mild [ ] Moderate [ ]

Locations

The Cogs (Sharn District)

  • Industrial Hellscape
  • Every Shadow Hides Danger
  • Daask Territory
  • When scenes happen here, these aspects are always available.

Organizations

Morgrave University

  • Knowledge Above All (Ethics Secondary)
  • Funding Problems
  • The Best Collection of Stolen Artifacts in Khorvaire
  • Skills: Lore Great (+4), Resources Fair (+2), Academics Good (+3)
  • Use these ratings when the organization acts or when characters invoke institutional resources.

The Mourning

The Day of Mourning destroyed Cyre four years ago. No one knows why. This is the central mystery of Eberron—and you should have an answer (or several possible answers) in mind for your campaign.

Possible Causes:

  • House Cannith experiment gone catastrophically wrong
  • Overlord breaking free (briefly or partially)
  • Accumulated magical weapons reached critical mass
  • The Draconic Prophecy demanded it
  • An attack from Dal Quor
  • A piece of Xoriat bleeding through
  • Something the Cyrans did to themselves (accidentally or deliberately)
  • Something no mortal yet understands

Using the Mourning:

  • The Mournland itself is an adventure location
  • Cyran refugees are everywhere, providing hooks
  • Fear of another Mourning motivates political action
  • Artifacts from pre-Mourning Cyre are valuable
  • The truth is a campaign-level prize

Running Magic and Artifice

When Players Use Narrative Magic

When a player describes their skill roll as magical, let them. The wizard using Lore to create an advantage might describe casting Detect Magic. The cleric using Will to defend might invoke divine protection.

The rule: magic describes how, not what. The skill determines what’s mechanically possible. Magic just makes it look cool.

When Players Research or Create

Brainstorms and inventions let players tackle problems creatively. Be generous with what they can attempt, but honest about difficulty and complications.

Brainstorm Difficulty Guidelines:

  • 2 aspects: Straightforward magical problem
  • 3 aspects: Complex working with multiple components
  • 4+ aspects: Major undertaking, possibly dangerous

Invention Complication Examples:

  • Requires rare materials (adventure hook)
  • Draws unwanted attention
  • Has unexpected side effects
  • Only works under specific conditions
  • Requires ongoing maintenance

When Magic Goes Wrong

Magic failing should create story, not just penalties.

  • Divination shows partial truths that mislead
  • Summoning attracts something other than intended
  • Wards alert the people they were supposed to hide from
  • Healing has unforeseen consequences
  • Illusions reveal truths the caster didn’t know

Appendix: Sharn Quick Reference

Sharn is organized into plateaus (Menthis, Central, etc.) and towers rising from those plateaus. Each plateau has upper, middle, and lower wards.

Upper Wards

  • Wealthy, safe, clean
  • Dragonmarked enclaves
  • Government offices
  • Expensive everything
  • “Looking down on everyone”

Middle Wards

  • Working class, merchants
  • Entertainment districts
  • Temples and shrines
  • Universities
  • Where most people live

Lower Wards

  • Poverty, crime, industry
  • Boromar and Daask territory
  • Dangerous after dark
  • Forgotten by those above
  • Where adventure lives

The Cogs

  • Below everything
  • Forges and foundries
  • Warforged laborers
  • Daask strongholds
  • Some things should stay buried

Getting Around

  • Skycoaches (taxis)
  • Lifts (elevators between wards)
  • Bridges (connect towers)
  • Flight (if you can manage it)
  • Falling (always an option)
